question: Question_04_(b)
statement:
Suppose that \emph{p} is an odd prime. Then show that

$\displaystyle 1^{2} \cdot 3^{2} \cdot 5^{2} \cdot ... \cdot (p-2)^{2} \equiv (-1)^{(p+1)/2} \mod{p}$
hints: Try to find a way to make use of Wilson's Theorem.

Multiply the product by $\displaystyle (-1)^{p-1}$. Write each square
like

$\displaystyle 1^{2} \equiv (1)(-1) \mod{p}$.

making use of all the negative one powers you included. Then add
\emph{p} to all the negative terms and examine what you get.
